> [{quoted}](name=ZaFishbone,realm=EUNE,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=W26q4AMY,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-08-31T07:57:47.698+0000)
>
> Gameplay+ = (Gameplay)++;

This would be evaluated in languages than could handle it as:

Gameplay += Gameplay++;

Which, in C/C++, would assign to Gameplay the value of Gameplay+Gameplay, which is finally incremented by 1, for an equivalent expression of 2\*Gameplay+1 . Java and JavaScript, on the other hand, would increment Gameplay by 1 first, but would add to Gameplay the _old_ value of Gameplay and then assign that back to Gameplay, overwriting the brief Gameplay+1 that Gameplay used to have, for an equivalent expression of 2\*Gameplay.

If you used pre-increment instead, C/C++ would produce 2\*(Gameplay+1) while Java and JS would produce Gameplay+(Gameplay+1).

As far as I can hypothesize, Python assignment expressions in 3.8 will treat the closest approximation of Gameplay := Gameplay + (Gameplay := Gameplay + 1) as Gameplay+(Gameplay+1), according to my dictionary-as-namespace setup. But that's more of a pre-increment situation - I don't currently see how to emulate a post-increment, since integers aren't even mutable in Python.

Overall, I'd recommend not mutating a variable while you're mutating it. In any language.

Of course, a Gameplay object could have custom behavior for these operators rather than behaving like an integer, so who knows.
Notepad++ is really great. I don't even use an IDE.
